text: What are your thoughts on doing tests as part of the interview process?  Keen to hear from a Tech Recruiters side.

<@U0F5K9GT1>: if I were to be hiring someone. I'd look at past projects (hobby project or 'professional'). It not only shows their passion, but also their experience. Even if they haven't done any work in the language you're hiring for, it doesn't mean they're bad developers. Good developers will pick it up quickly no matter what it is (them applying for the job offer also shows their interest of course). So imo tests don't validate much, they validate that someone can perhaps memorise some programming, but not much more. You cannot determine in a short timeframe and with a tiny project whether they're a good developer.
So in the interview, look at their personality and before the interview look at how good of a developer the person is I would say.

I do not personally like relying on the tests. If the test is just one part of the interview then great but you should look at a person as their whole like <@U061HDV96> is saying rather than their ability to nervously solve a white board problem while people are staring at them.

good and great developers are often obvious when you look at their github profiles (though not all good and great developers have a lot of public work so this isn't always as easy) and in such a case the interview should almost be a personality check for your team.

We don’t do testing here, more a technical interview getting them to talk us through a solution they worked on - drawing it up on the whiteboard - and allowing a conversation throughout, deep diving and going through the decision process.  There are a few questions additional, but all relative to what someone has done and a focus on what they do outside of the dayjob/current project, how do they stay current and learning style.

does anyone have good example of a freelance contract? I’m about to get a spec and they asked for a proposal, and I’d like to take the same approach I do as development and copy paste as much as possible.
I have nothing to contribute to this, but I like your style :smile:
<@U053Q5XP2>: I once watched a talk of a lawyer and designer for freelance work. I think they put the contract online for free.
I'll check whether I can find it.
I think it was this video: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jVkLVRt6c1U>

attachments.title: Mike Monteiro: F*ck You, Pay Me
